COMP7103A - Data Mining (Semester 1, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7103A
   Course Name: Data Mining
   Instructor: Ben C.M. Kao
   Semester: Semester 1, 2025-26 Academic Year
   Pre-requisites: Nil
   Compatibility: Nil
   Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   Data mining is the automatic discovery of statistically interesting and potentially useful patterns from large amounts of data. The goal of this course is to study the main methods used today for data mining and on-line analytical processing.
   Advances in data collection and generation technologies are producing massive amounts of data from which valuable information and knowledge can be derived. This course covers various data mining techniques, powerful tools for data analysts to process data and extract interesting patterns and models—facilitating new scientific discoveries and intelligent business decisions.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understand the knowledge discovery process, including data collection, data cleaning, model building, model testing, and evaluation.
   CLO2: Understand various data mining tasks and the fundamental algorithms for achieving those tasks

process, including data collection, data cleaning, model building, model testing, and evaluation.
   CLO2: Understand various data mining tasks and the fundamental algorithms for achieving those tasks.
   Programme Learning Outcomes References
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(FTDA)
4. Course Content & Hour Allocation
   Topic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs
   1. Data Cleaning	4	CLO1
   2. Data Exploration	4	CLO1
   3. Ranking	6	CLO1
   4. Clustering	4	CLO2
   5. Association Rules	3	CLO2
   6. Recommender Systems	4	CLO2
   7. Advanced Applications	5	CLO1, CLO2
5. Assessment Scheme
   Assessment Type	Assessment Category	Weighting	Examination Period	Corresponding CLOs
   Assignments	Continuous Assessment	40%	-	-
   Midterm Exam	Continuous Assessment	10%	-	-
   Written Exam	Written Examination	50%	3 - 23 December 2025	CLO1, CLO2
   The weighting of coursework and examination marks is subject to approval.^ The exact examination date will be released after the add/drop period by the Examinations Office. Students are obliged to follow the examination schedule. Students should NOT enrol in the course if they are not certai

tion date will be released after the add/drop period by the Examinations Office. Students are obliged to follow the examination schedule. Students should NOT enrol in the course if they are not certain that they will be in Hong Kong during the examination period. Absence from the examination may result in failure in the course. There is no supplementary examination for all MSc curriculums in the Faculty of Engineering.

COMP7103B - Data Mining (Semester 1, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7103BCourse Name: Data MiningInstructor: Mauro SozioSemester: Semester 1, 2025-26 Academic YearCategory: Postgraduate (MSc(CompSc)/MSc(FTDA))Pre-requisites: NilCompatibility: NilMoodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   Data mining is the automatic discovery of statistically interesting and potentially useful patterns from large amounts of data. The goal of the course is to study the main methods used today for data mining and on-line analytical processing, including Data Mining Architecture, Data Preprocessing, Mining Association Rules, Classification, Clustering, OLAP, and Advanced Data Mining (Web, Spatial, Temporal data).
   Advances in data collection and generation technologies are producing massive amounts of data from which valuable information and knowledge can be derived. This course covers various data mining techniques—powerful tools for data analysts to process data and extract interesting patterns and models—enabling new scientific discoveries and intelligent business decisions.

act interesting patterns and models—enabling new scientific discoveries and intelligent business decisions.

COMP7104A - Advanced database systems(Semester 1, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7104A
   Course Name: Advanced database systems
   Instructor: Bogdan Cautis
   Semester: Semester 1, 2025-26 Academic Year
   Pre-requisites: A course of introduction to databases and basic programming skills. The course assumes basic prior knowledge on database systems (e.g., relational databases and SQL). Students should be familiar with at least one programming language such as Java, C++, Python, etc. and able to pick up other similar languages
   Compatibility: Nil
   Special Note: This course is co-coded with DASC7104 which is for MDASC students
   Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   We are living in the Big Data era, with virtually all innovation domains (medicine, finance, sports, physics, astronomy, etc.) becoming data-rich. Traditional database management systems (originally designed for efficient business data processing) have evolved rapidly, and new systems have emerged to support diverse data-intensive applications with specific characteristics and requirements. These applications are often characterized by the four "Vs" of Big Data: Volume (data size

s have emerged to support diverse data-intensive applications with specific characteristics and requirements. These applications are often characterized by the four "Vs" of Big Data: Volume (data size), Variety (data formats), Velocity (e.g., streaming sources), and Veracity (uncertain data, data reliability). Their requirements may relate to data storage architecture (e.g., cloud-based), fault tolerance, or flexibility of data/computation models. This course studies advanced topics and techniques in database systems, focusing on database design & algorithms and big data processing for structured data. Traditional topics include query optimization, physical database design, transaction management, crash recovery, and parallel databases. It also surveys recent developments in areas like NoSQL databases and SQL-based big data management systems for relational (structured) data. The course reviews data processing architectures and algorithms for managing large data quantities, covering both transactional processing and data analytics.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understand trade-offs in database systems techniques, able to apply acquired knowledge on the state-of-the-a

th transactional processing and data analytics.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understand trade-offs in database systems techniques, able to apply acquired knowledge on the state-of-the-art in modern data management for designing holistic solutions based on database systems and techniques, justify design decisions in the context of a data management solution
   CLO2: Able to implement and evaluate complex, scalable database systems solutions, develop new methods in databases based on acquired knowledge of existing techniques
   Programme Learning Outcomes References:
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)
4. Course Content & Hour Allocation
   Topic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs
   Query processing and optimization for relational database systems	6	CLO1, CLO2
   Transaction management and crash recovery	6	CLO1, CLO2
   Indexing methods	3	CLO1, CLO2
   Parallel database systems	4.5	CLO1, CLO2
   Cloud-based and composable database systems	6	CLO1, CLO2
   NoSQL systems	4.5	CLO1, CLO2
5. Assessment Scheme
   Assessment Type	Assessment Category	Weighting	Examination Period	Corresponding CLOs
   Laboratory	Continuous Assessment	25%	-	CLO1, CLO2
   Writt

NoSQL systems	4.5	CLO1, CLO2

COMP7106A - Big Data Management (Semester 2, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7106ACourse Name: Big Data ManagementInstructor: Reynold C.K. ChengSemester: Semester 2, 2025-26 Academic Year (tentative)Category: Postgraduate (MSc(CompSc))Pre-requisites: The student is expected to have taken a course on introduction to databases (e.g., COMP3278), and has some background in statistics and calculus.Compatibility: Students who have obtained credits for any of the following courses are not allowed to take COMP7106: 1. COMP7107 Management of complex types; 2. COMP7105 Advanced topics in data science; 3. COMP7801 in the academic year 2019-20, 2020-21Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   The course will study some advanced topics and techniques in Big Data, and survey the recent development and progress in specific areas in big data management and scalable data science. Topics include but not limited to: large database management techniques, spatial data management and spatial networks, data quality and uncertain databases, top-k queries, graph and text databases, and data analytics.
   Advances in big data technologies have led to an explosion of data volum

ent and spatial networks, data quality and uncertain databases, top-k queries, graph and text databases, and data analytics.
   Advances in big data technologies have led to an explosion of data volume and complexity. This course equips students with core skills to manage and analyze large-scale data—covering both theoretical foundations (e.g., uncertain data modeling) and practical techniques (e.g., spatial data query optimization)—preparing them for roles in data engineering and scalable data science.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Able to understand the background and knowledge of some advanced topics in Big Data that have become key techniques in modern database theory and practices.CLO2: Able to understand the background and knowledge of some contemporary topics in Big Data research (e.g., uncertainty data management, text, and graph databases).Programme Learning Outcomes ReferencesView Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)

   Topic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs
   1. Review of database design, queries, and indexing	-	CLO1
   2. Spatial data management	-	CLO1, CLO2
   3. Spatial networks	-	CLO1, CLO2
   4. Ranking

opic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs

   6. Uncertain databases	-	CLO1, CLO2
   7. Probabilistic Queries	-	CLO1, CLO2
   8. Uncertain data mining	-	CLO2

COMP7106B - Big Data Management (Semester 2, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7106BCourse Name: Big Data ManagementInstructor: Reynold C.K. ChengSemester: Semester 2, 2025-26 Academic Year (tentative)Category: Postgraduate (MSc(CompSc))Pre-requisites: The student is expected to have taken a course on introduction to databases (e.g., COMP3278), and has some background in statistics and calculus.Compatibility: Students who have obtained credits for any of the following courses are not allowed to take COMP7106: 1. COMP7107 Management of complex types; 2. COMP7105 Advanced topics in data science; 3. COMP7801 in the academic year 2019-20, 2020-21Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   The course will study some advanced topics and techniques in Big Data, and survey the recent development and progress in specific areas in big data management and scalable data science. Topics include but not limited to: large database management techniques, spatial data management and spatial networks, data quality and uncertain databases, top-k queries, graph and text databases, and data analytics.
   Advances in big data technologies have led to an explosion of data volum

ent and spatial networks, data quality and uncertain databases, top-k queries, graph and text databases, and data analytics.
   Advances in big data technologies have led to an explosion of data volume and complexity. This course equips students with core skills to manage and analyze large-scale data—covering both theoretical foundations (e.g., uncertain data modeling) and practical techniques (e.g., spatial data query optimization)—preparing them for roles in data engineering and scalable data science.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Able to understand the background and knowledge of some advanced topics in Big Data that have become key techniques in modern database theory and practices.CLO2: Able to understand the background and knowledge of some contemporary topics in Big Data research (e.g., uncertainty data management, text, and graph databases).Programme Learning Outcomes ReferencesView Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)
4. Course Content & Hour Allocation

   1. Review of database design, queries, and indexing	-	CLO1
   2. Spatial data management	-	CLO1, CLO2
   3. Spatial networks	-	CLO1, CLO2
   4. Ranking

opic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs

COMP7107A - Management of complex data types(Semester 1, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7107A
   Course Name: Management of complex data types
   Instructor: Nikos Mamoulis
   Semester: Semester 1, 2025-26 Academic Year
   Pre-requisites: Nil
   Compatibility: Students who have obtained credits for any of the following courses are not allowed to take COMP7107: 1. COMP7106 Big data management 2. COMP7105 Advanced topics in data science
   Prior knowledge expected: Programming knowledge and scientific background at the level of a BSc degree in Computer Science or equivalent
   Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   More and more data are available through automatic collection tools in various formats. As data volume and variety increase, data processing systems need specialized indexing and query evaluation techniques for complex and composite data management. This course studies the management of non-traditional and complex data types beyond relational tabular data. It first provides background on classic indexing and query evaluation methods for relational databases, then covers techniques for complex data types including spatial, temporal, and sp

tabular data. It first provides background on classic indexing and query evaluation methods for relational databases, then covers techniques for complex data types including spatial, temporal, and spatio-temporal data; multidimensional feature vectors; sparse vectors and set-valued data; strings, sequences and time-series; general and knowledge-base graphs; geo-social and geo-textual data. It also covers data storage methods for disk and main-memory.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understand the nature of complex data and the challenges in managing and querying composite data objects in main memory and on the disk
   CLO2: Learn popular techniques for managing and searching spatial, temporal, spatio-temporal, multidimensional point data, time-series, strings, and sequences
   CLO3: Learn techniques for representing and accessing large-scale sparse and dense sets, graphs and knowledge bases; Learn access methods and search algorithms for composite data (geo-textual and geo-social)
   Programme Learning Outcomes References:
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MDASC
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)
4. Course Content & Hour Allocation
   Topic Covered	N

-social)
   Programme Learning Outcomes References:
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MDASC
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)
4. Course Content & Hour Allocation
   Topic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs
   Background on relational data management and query evaluation	3	CLO1
   Simple and complex data types	3	CLO1
   Spatial and multidimensional data	6	CLO2
   Advanced queries and analysis tasks on multidimensional data	3	CLO2
   Time-series, strings, and sequences	3	CLO2
   Temporal and spatio-temporal data	3	CLO2
   Set-valued objects and sparse vector data	3	CLO3
   Graph data and link analysis, analysis of big social network graphs, RDF data management	3	CLO3
   Composite data (geo-textual and geo-social)	3	CLO3
5. Assessment Scheme
   Assessment Type	Assessment Category	Weighting	Examination Period	Corresponding CLOs
   Assignment 1 (written and programming)	Continuous Assessment	15%	-	CLO1
   Assignment 2 (written and programming)	Continuous Assessment	20%	-	CLO2
   Assignment 3 (written and programming)	Continuous Assessment	15%	-	CLO3
   Written Exam (covers all taught content)	Written Examination	50%	3 - 23 December 2025	CLO1, CLO2, CLO3
   The w

20%	-	CLO2
   Assignment 3 (written and programming)	Continuous Assessment	15%	-	CLO3
   Written Exam (covers all taught content)	Written Examination	50%	3 - 23 December 2025	CLO1, CLO2, CLO3

COMP7404A - Computational intelligence and machine learning(Semester 1, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7404A
   Course Name: Computational intelligence and machine learning
   Instructor: Dirk Schnieders
   Semester: Semester 1, 2025-26 Academic Year
   Pre-requisites: Nil, but knowledge of data structures and algorithms, probability, linear algebra, and programming would be an advantage
   Compatibility: Nil
   Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   This course covers several topics in AI and ML. It starts with traditional AI techniques including search, probability estimation, and Bayes rule, then moves to machine learning techniques such as unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and supervised learning. AI and ML are highly interdisciplinary fields with impacts in applications like biology, robotics, language, economics, and computer science. AI is the science and engineering of making intelligent machines, especially intelligent computer programs, while ML refers to changes in systems that perform AI-related tasks. Ethical issues in advanced AI and methods to prevent learning algorithms from acquiring morally undesirable biases are als

rograms, while ML refers to changes in systems that perform AI-related tasks. Ethical issues in advanced AI and methods to prevent learning algorithms from acquiring morally undesirable biases are also covered.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understand the fundamental concepts of computational intelligence and machine learning
   CLO2: Demonstrate awareness of the major challenges and risks facing computational intelligence and the complexity of typical problems within the field
   CLO3: Able to implement solutions to various problems in computational intelligence
   Programme Learning Outcomes References:
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MDASC
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(CompSc)
   View Programme Learning Outcomes - MSc(ECom&IComp)

   Topic Covered	No. of Hours	Corresponding CLOs
   Introduction	2	CLO1, CLO2
   Search, Probability Estimation, Bayes Rule	7	CLO1, CLO2, CLO3
   Unsupervised Machine Learning / Reinforcement Learning	7	CLO1, CLO2, CLO3
   Supervised Machine Learning	8	CLO1, CLO2, CLO3
   Group Presentations	6	CLO3

COMP7404B - Computational intelligence and machine learning(Semester 2, 2025-26)
1. Basic Information
   Course Code: COMP7404B
   Course Name: Computational intelligence and machine learning
   Instructor: Dong Xu
   Semester: Semester 2, 2025-26 Academic Year
   Pre-requisites: Nil, but knowledge of data structures and algorithms, probability, linear algebra, and programming would be an advantage
   Compatibility: Nil
   Moodle Course Website: [TBA]
2. Course Introduction
   This course will teach a broad set of principles and tools that provide the mathematical, algorithmic and philosophical framework for tackling problems using Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML). AI and ML are highly interdisciplinary fields with impacts in applications like biology, robotics, language, economics, and computer science. AI is the science and engineering of making intelligent machines, especially intelligent computer programs, while ML refers to changes in systems that perform AI-related tasks. Ethical issues in advanced AI and methods to prevent learning algorithms from acquiring morally undesirable biases are also covered.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understa

related tasks. Ethical issues in advanced AI and methods to prevent learning algorithms from acquiring morally undesirable biases are also covered.
3. Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs)
   CLO1: Understand the fundamental concepts of computational intelligence and machine learning
   CLO2: Demonstrate awareness of the major challenges and risks facing computational intelligence and the complexity of typical problems within the field
   CLO3: Able to implement solutions to various problems in computational intelligence

   Supervised Machine Learning	8	CLO1, CLO2, CLO3
   Group Presentations	6	CLO3
